abstract_summ: In the United States (U.S.), there have been over 2,000,000 confirmed cases and over 110,000 confirmed deaths.The results visualize the space-time evolution and dynamics of COVID-19 clusters in the State of Sao Paulo.We detect statistically significant space-time clusters of COVID-19 at the county level in the U.S. between January 22nd-March 9th, 2020, and January 22nd-March 27th, 2020.These results can inform health authorities and public management to take the necessary measures to minimize the transmission of COVID-19 and track the evolution of significant space-time clusters.There currently lacks a study that showcases the novelty of daily COVID-19 surveillance using space-time cluster detection techniques.
title_summ: Applying a Prospective Space-Time Scan Statistic to Examine the Evolution of COVID-19 Clusters in the State of Sao Paulo, BrazilUse of excess mortality associated with the COVID-19 epidemic as an epidemiological surveillance strategy - preliminary results of the evaluation of six Brazilian capitalsEstimation of the number of general anesthesia cases based on a series of nationwide surveys on Twitter during COVID-19 in Japan: A statistical analysisUsing altmetrics for detecting impactful research in quasi-zero-day time-windows: the case of COVID-19Epidemiological data from the COVID-19 outbreak, real-time case informationRapid surveillance of COVID-19 in the United States using a prospective space-time scan statistic: Detecting and evaluating emerging clustersDaily Surveillance of COVID-19 using the Prospective Space-Time Scan Statistic in the United StatesSurveillance of the first cases of COVID-19 in Sergipe using a prospective spatiotemporal analysis: the spatial dispersion and its public health implications
title_abstract_phrases: In the United States (U.S.), there have been over 2,000,000 confirmed cases and over 110,000 confirmed deaths.Applying a Prospective Space-Time Scan Statistic to Examine the Evolution of COVID-19 Clusters in the State of Sao Paulo, BrazilWe present the first geographic study that uses space-time statistics to monitor COVID-19 in Brazil.Surveillance of the first cases of COVID-19 in Sergipe using a prospective spatiotemporal analysis: the spatial dispersion and its public health implicationsINTRODUCTION: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has become a global public health emergency with lethality ranging from 1% to 5%.The results visualize the space-time evolution and dynamics of COVID-19 clusters in the State of Sao Paulo.Considering the simplicity of the method, its low cost and reliability for assessing the real burden of the disease, we believe that the assessment of excess mortality associated with the COVID-19 pandemic should be widely used as a complementary tool to regular epidemiological surveillance and its use should be encouraged by WHO.Estimation of the number of general anesthesia cases based on a series of nationwide surveys on Twitter during COVID-19 in Japan: A statistical analysisCoronavirus disease (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), was first reported in Wuhan, Hubei, China, and has since spread to more than 200 other countries at the time of writing.
